required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on November 19, 2021
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: A Study to Evaluate JAK Inhibitor Cream in EGFR-inhibitor-induced Skin Rash
clinical_study.official_title: An Investigator-initiated Trial to Evaluate the Efficacy and Safety of JAK Inhibitor Cream for the Treatment of EGFR-inhibitor-induced Skin Rash

brief_summary.textblock: Epidermal growth factor receptor inhibitors (EGFRIs) are widely used targeted agents that have been approved for the treatment of various tumor types. In some clinical studies with EGFRIs, the incidence of dermatology AE, the skin rash, is reportedly as high as 95%, which profoundly impact the patients' quality of life. However no treament for onset skin rash has been approved to be effective by any clinical trial yet. Janus kinase (JAK) inhibitor, has been approved for or studied in a variety of skin conditions such as alopecia areata, atopic dermatitis, and psoriasis. Thus we intend to evaluate the efficacy and safety of JAK inhibitor cream for the treatment of EGFRIs-induced skin rash in cancer patients.

study_design_info.masking: Quadruple (Participant, Care Provider, Investigator, Outcomes Assessor)

primary_outcome.measure: Proportion of grade 0 or 1 patients at Week 4
primary_outcome.description: Determine the proportion of patients receiving JAK Inhibitor Cream or Vehicle who have achieved grade 0 or 1 skin rash (according to MESTT criteria) at Week 4

secondary_outcome.measure: Proportion of grade 0 or 1 patients at Week 2
secondary_outcome.description: Determine the proportion of patients receiving JAK Inhibitor Cream or Vehicle who have achieved grade 0 or 1 skin rash (according to MESTT criteria) at Week 2

secondary_outcome.measure: Proportion of grade 0 or 1 patients at Week 6
secondary_outcome.description: Determine the proportion of patients receiving JAK Inhibitor Cream or Vehicle who have achieved grade 0 or 1 skin rash (according to MESTT criteria) at Week 6

secondary_outcome.measure: Change of QoL (PRO) from baseline at Week 4
secondary_outcome.description: Determine the Change of QoL (PRO) from baseline in patients receiving JAK Inhibitor Cream or Vehicle at Week 4
Safety of study drug as determined by number of participants with abnormal laboratory values and/or Adverse Events that are related to study treatment, especially local irritation.

intervention.description: The study drug is a cream containing JAK Inhibitor.
The vehicle cream contains no JAK Inhibitor but with the same base as study drug.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- 18 years of age or older.
- Pathologically conÔ¨Årmed cancer receiving EGFRI-based therapy (monotherapy or as part of a combination therapy regimen).
- Skin rash causally related to EGFRI therapy of grade 1 or higher (according to MESTT criteria).
- ECOG performance score < 2.
- Able to use topical medications and complete questionnaires reliably with or without assistance.
- Life expectancy of greater than 6 months.
- Ability to understand and the willingness to sign a written informed consent.
Exclusion Criteria:
- Use of any other topical medications in the treatment areas (face) within 7 days prior to randomization or duing the study.
- Use of Tetracycline (e.g. minocycline, doxycycline) within 14 days prior to randomization or duing the study.
- Use of other cancer medications known to result in skin rash in the face or upper chest/upper back area within 4 weeks prior to randomization or duing the study.
- Known hypersentitivity to JAK inhibitors.
- With other skin disorders that may affect efficacy evaluation, including but not limited to: eczema, psoriasis, etc.
- Uncontrolled intercurrent illness.
- Significantly abnormal lab test.
- Pregnant or nursing women.
